author: Tom Payne For The Daily Mail
title: First Great Western believes that if customers want the best deal, they should ask for it
text:
180 shares 441
View
comments
Train passengers should find the cheapest fares themselves because companies are under 'no obligation' to do it for them, one of Britain's biggest rail firms has claimed.
First Great Western said its staff are told to presume that passengers have already looked for the cheapest deals before they make a purchase.
The firm reportedly said in emails sent to customers: 'By the time the passenger is requesting their tickets at the booking office, it is assumed they have already made the necessary enquiries into available fare options, and are asking for the fare they want.
Scroll down for video
First Great Western said its staff are told to presume that passengers have already looked for the cheapest deals before they make a purchase
TIPS FOR SAVING MONEY Singles often beat returns: Some of the best deals are available on advance one-way fares, meaning it is often cheaper to buy two singles rather than one return. It can even sometimes be cheaper to buy a first-class single rather than a standard-class ticket. Check your journey up to 12 weeks early: Network Rail must have the timetable set 12 weeks in advance, so operators usually release their cheap advance tickets soon after. You can sign up to alerts from operators to find out when specific advance tickets are available. Most advance tickets are on sale until up to 6pm the day before. Buy a railcard: Most Railcards cost £30 per year - or £70 for three - and cut a third off the price of many tickets. You can even get discounts on a Railcard itself. They are available for families, people aged 16 to 25, those aged over 60, the disabled and any two people travelling together. 'It therefore remains the passenger's responsibility to ensure they're asking for the fare that is best for their particular requirements or at least to instigate the necessary enquiries'.
The firm also said if customers want the best deal, they should ask for it specifically.
The email continued: 'I realise it would be a more positive experience for our customers if our booking office colleagues do provide any alternatives or extra information at the time of booking … but they are under no obligation to offer anything other than that which has been asked for.'
A spokesman confirmed the email reflected its policy, which is understood not to be illegal.
Last night rail minister Claire Perry told The Daily Telegraph train firms 'must get better at giving their customers information about ticket options in a straightforward way'.
She said: 'The most important part of the railway is its customers, and they must be able to trust that they are getting the best possible deal every time they travel.
'If this is not happening it is unacceptable.' Martin Abrams of the Campaign for Better Transport added that passengers were being burdened by a 'hugely overcomplicated' fares system.

THE TRAIN FARE TRICK THAT CAN SAVE RAILWAY USERS MILLIONS While passengers may not be able to secure the cheapest fares from rail firm staff or ticket kiosks, they have a friend in a handful of websites or smartphone apps.
One of those websites, TrainSplit.com, is helping travellers buy cheaper ‘split tickets’ thanks to a secret computer code which finds cut-price fares normally hidden from the public.
With split tickets, passengers break up their trip into legs instead of a single-ticket journey – offering a lower combined fare while travelling on the same train.
The website claims its tool can save an average of 22 per cent on the fares listed on train company websites.
For example, a single off-peak ticket from Plymouth to Derby can cost £129.50 using the Trainline site. But buying four separate, single tickets for the route costs just £60.83 – a saving of £68.67.
The train has to stop at the stations where all the tickets are valid to and from, but passengers need not get off.
TrainSplit.com said split tickets aren’t offered at station ticket machines or by any train company websites, and staff are under no obligation to search for them.
Smartphone app and website TicketySplit, offered by consumer website MoneySavingExpert, also helps to save on fares with split tickets.
Consumers can use the app to find out if it is cheaper to buy multiple tickets on the same journey without having to change trains.
Ticket splitting is legal in the UK, and the emphasis is on the user to work out how to find the best deal.
Last year it emerged that self-service ticket machines – used to buy almost a quarter of tickets every year – offer vastly different fares to those bought in a booking office.
An investigation found some tickets cost £200 from a machine compared with £100 for the same destination bought elsewhere.
It followed calls for an urgent inquiry into 'rip off' ticket machines by the Transport Salaried Staffs' Association union.
Manuel Cortes, the TSSA's general secretary, said in October: 'Millions of rail passengers are paying much higher fares than they should be simply because they are being systematically ripped off at self- service machines.'
